items.title: The day book. [volume]
note: "An adless daily newspaper."
Archived issues are available in digital format as part of the Library of Congress Chronicling America online collection.
Available on microfilm;
Description based on: Nov. 1, 1911.
Issue for <Nov. 24, 1911> lacks vol., no., and chronological designation.
Issue for Nov. 4, 1911 erroneously designated as Oct. 4, 1911.
Issue for v. 3, no. 290 (Sept. 7, 1914) erroneously designated as v. 3, no. 300 (Sept. 7, 1914). The error in numbering continues.
Issue for v. 5, no. 214 (June 7, 1916) erroneously designated as v. 5, no. 214 (June 6, 1916).
Issue for v. 5, no. 7 (Oct. 5, 1915) erroneously designated as v. 5, no. 7 (Sept. 5, 1915).
Issues for <May 7-17, 1915> called also "Moving Picture Edition."
Issues have no page numbering.

Saturdays have Noon and Final editions, Dec. 28, 1912-June 21, 1913; Saturdays have Noon and Last editions, June 28, 1913-<Dec. 13, 1913>; began issuing daily Noon and Last editions, Dec. 20, 1913-July 6, 1917.
Vol. 5, no. 36 (Nov. 6, 1915) issue called also "Garment Workers' Special Edition."
Volume numbering begins with Nov. 20, 1911 issue.

items.ocr_eng:
The Biggest Kind of a Change that ever
Happened to Any Magazine has
Happened This Month to
THE
SCRAPS
BGDK
THE SCRAP BOOK. FOR JULY IS ISSUED IN TWO SECTIONS— TWO
complete magazine*, each with its own cover and its own table of content*.
One of these section! is an ALL-ILLUSTRATED magazine; the other is an
ALL-FICTION magazine. Each is a mammoth magazine in itself. The one
presents an overwhelming array of human interest articles and illustrations;
the other an enormous tonnage of fiction — 160 pages of absorbing stories.
Ten years ago I created a new type of magazine — the ALL-FICTION
magazine. Now I am creating another distinct type — the ALL-ILLUS
TRATED magazine. This is the age of specialization. The conventional
magazine, with its smattering of illustrations and its smattering of fiction
and its smattering of special articles, doesn't contain enough of any one
thing to make it satisfying. The ALL-FICTION magazine and the ALL
ILLUSTRATED magazine, joined together as a unit, make something really
big and forceful and convincing.
The Only Way to Know a Thing is to Try It
The TW< >-SECTION magazine idea is brand new to the world. It is a t qmte
new with me, however, as I have given it. at odd times, four or five rears
of thought. It first came into my mind in response to a desire to couple, in
some way, the strength of the all fiction magazine with the illustrated features
of the conventional magazine. It has been a difficult problem to work er.t.
Now that the idea is perfected, I wish to see what there is m it. 11 looks to
me to ! c very good, but the only way to know a thing is to try it.
Two Magazines for Quarter Easy Money
The price of this two-part magazine is twenty-jive cents, which is equal to twelve ard
one-half cents a magazine. A/03/ magazines which were telling at ten cents have Yen
advanced to fifteen cents. THE SCRAP BOOK in koo parts means two magazines
for twenty-five cents against thirty cents for two fifteen cent magazines.
Mow Ready on all News-stands
FRANK A. MUNSEY, New Yorh.

items.ocr_eng:
6
NEW BRITAIN DAILY HERALD, FRIDAY, APRIL 22, 1927.
im,,,!
JU
ill
4 DEI
Hill ifll
r jii. hiiiiiiii miiiiii HiiHi
Vv Mil III
WHO killed Garrett Fosom? And what for? One
moment this middle-aged, handsome bachelor was
a gay and laughing figure, one of a great throng of holi
day revelers bathing in the glorious surf of Ocean Town.
One moment he was exchanging pleasantries with his
friends; the next he was a stricken man, limp and life
less beneath the waves. Life guards carried him out of
the water. They laid him on the beach, while the
curious gathered and stared in awe.
Drowning? No. Stroke? No. Death had come as
the result of a powerful knife thrust beneath the water;
a thrust sure and deadly, but from what source no one
knew. Detectives, Garrett Folsom's friends, even those
who had stood next to him when the murder was com
mitted, were truly
ALL
AT
And so Carolyn Wells, truly titled the "mistress of mystery" because of her mastery of the detective story, has
aptly named this latest work of hers "All at Sea." You have never read a story like it, never encountered
a murder plot so baffling and strange.
This new story by ihe famous Carolyn
Wells is the first serial she has written di
rectly for newspaper publication. Don t
miss it. It starts in The Herald Friday,
April 29.
It is just one more reason for your reading
your fiction in The Herald. The Herald
has exclusive rights in New Britain to NEA
Service and NEA Service fiction. That
means it is the only paper here that prints
original fiction stories by such authors as
Anne Austin, Carolyn Wells, Virginia Swain
and Ernest Lvnn.
The wealthy Garrett Folsom murdered. No clue except the knife, the
deadly "pichag." Finger .prints washed away by the salt water; foot
prints lost irrevocably in the shifting sands. Who did it, and why?
Was money the motive? Was revenge? Was jealousy?
If you are a Carolyn Wells "fan," be prepared for a thousand thrills in
the latest story of hers. If you've never read her work, "all at Sea"
will explain her popularity as a writer of mystery fiction.
Remember, "All at Sea" is written directly for newspaper publication.
It is not a reprint from a book. It is NEA Service fiction, which means
original fiction.
ill

Bruce Barton's Common-Sense Editorial
tfjQSCTOT'"'"
Masters of Fiction!
Ask any man or woman you chance to meet, to name, offhand, a
few of the world's greatest writers Invariably this challenge will
bring names of great writers of FICTION
This should drive home to every alert and open mind the fact that
Fiction is the form of most universal appeal in interpreting Life
Every human being sees life as a drama The big, vital steps of life
are based on Feeling Feeling perhaps tempered and controlled by
Reason but Feeling just the same!
Literature without the play of these forces and having no power to
make the reader feel, at least in a measure, as the men and women
felt who left their impress upon their day, is not the kind of Litera
ture that lingers in the human heart
This is why the Masters of Fiction have enshrined themselves so
securely in the affections of readers that they are first on the tongue
when names of Great Writers are demanded
No period in the world's history ever offered the opportunity to the
artist in Fiction that confronts the story-writers of today And in
this field of literary art there are a score of competent craftsmen
where there was one a half-century ago.
This is one reason why THE RED BOOK MAGAZINE has become one
of the most powerful educational forces in America; it realizes that
Fiction is the Master Art in the interpretation-of Life It publishes
only Fiction, and the best obtainable Fiction which portrays the
feelings that are shaping the destiny of Today and Tomorrow
THE RED BOO

items.ocr_eng:
OW often do you hear
people say ? " How
shall we kill the
evening?"
Think of killing time, man's
most precious asset!
Why not use an evening ?
this evening if you will.
If you like fiction, read the
kind that will stimulate your
imagination ? that will inspire
and entertain you.
That means fiction by really
great, really important writers.
Such fiction is more than mere
entertainment ? it is literature
? the best and finest literature
of our day.
It isn't what we say about
these writers that makes them
great. ? It's what you tinelli
gent,c progressive magazine
readers think about themthat
establishes their reputation.
That's why the American
public pays more for the privi
lege of reading Cosmopolitan
than it pays for the single
edition of any other magazine.
For it is the policy of
Cosmopolitan to give the
magazine readers of America
the best magazine that it is
possible to produce .
The best editorially , the
best mechanically ? every
month in the year, and year
after year.
?J* "v
When you get the December
number of Cosmopolitan you
will have the satisfaction of
knowing that you have the
best magazine that money can
buy .J
More ? when you read it you
know that you are doing
something more profitable
than "killing time" ? you are
using it to the best possible
advantage that the reading of
fiction gives.
It was Lord Francis Bacon
who said, " reading serves for
delight , for ornament , for
ability. The crafty condemn it ,
the simple admire it, the wise
use it
And the better part of wis
dom in reading is to read the
best literature of the day.
That means Cosmopolitan .

ornament, for ability. The crafty
condemn it, the simple admire it, the
wise use it."
And the better part of wisdom
in reading is to read the best lit
erature of the day.
That means Cosmopolitan.

note: Also available in digital format on the Library of Congress website.
Archived issues are available in digital format as part of the Library of Congress Chronicling America online collection.
Available on microfilm from University Microfilms International, and Recordak.
Evening ed.: Evening edition of the tribune, 1866.
Merged with: New York herald (New York, N.Y. : 1920); to form: New York herald, New York tribune.
Semiweekly ed.: New-York tribune (New York, N.Y. : 1866 : Semiweekly), 1866-<1899>.
Triweekly eds.: New-York tri-weekly tribune, <1900>-1903, and: New York tribune (New York, N.Y. : 1903), 1903-<1909>.
Weekly ed.: New-York tribune (New York, N.Y. : 1866 : Weekly), 1866-<1906>.
items.ocr_eng:
"Little Nell and Her Grandfather"
(The Old Curiosity Shop, by Charles Dickens)
From a "Veriplica" Painting After Arthur I). McCormick
Your memory of Di?kens'.s "Old Curiosity Shop" responds
instantly to the truth and charm of the artist's conception
of two of the best loved characters in fiction the winsome
child, who mothered old Trent through his weakness and
wandering, and the pathetic old deceiver, whose sole ambi?
tion was to gamble and win great riches for Little Nell.

items.ocr_eng:
SCIENCE OH A SPREE
by Leslie Lieber
— tNCE EXPERT John W. Campbell "invents" fantastic gadgets in his home lab
Don't laugh at screwball science fiction. It's
full of space ships and robots, but the gadgets
are often bull's-eye predictions of things to come
THE first atom-bomb explo
sion in history did not
take place July 16, 1945, on a
New Mexico desert. Actually,
Α-Bomb No. 1 exploded a
good 15 years before that — on page 56 of
"Astounding Science Fiction Magazine."
The writer who described that holocaust
not only used Uranium-235 in his story, but
accurately foretold the strength of the explo
sion and its deadly after-effects.
Just a fluke prediction? Perhaps. But what
about science fiction's next stroke of clair
voyance? Just a short time after Pearl Harbor,
another pulp-magazine yarn described the
dropping of an atomic empire-buster on
Japan. That's the way science fiction end
ed the war, ami that'» the way history
wound it up three years later.
Now, if those two were the only successful
"guesses," we could just chalk the whole thing
up to some author's pipe-dreaming type
writer, and let the whole matter drop.
history. By far the great majority of them are
men (the outer reaches of space are pioneer
regions unfit for feminine habitation).
Many readers are distinguished citizens of
the worldof non-fiction science. "Astounding,"
for example, claims among its fans several
physics professors, including Dr. J. R. Oppen
heimer and fellow atomic scientists; R. S.
Richardson, solar specialist of Mt. Wilson
Observatory; John R. Pierce, inventor of the
traveling wave amplifier; Willy Ley, author
of "Rockets."
Big-nun· By-lincc
When Dr. Herman J. Muller, a recent Nobel
Prize winner, left for Stockholm to receive
his award, he was photographed with his face
buried in a copy of "Astounding."
Among the men of academic achievement
whose by-lines have often appeared on SF
pieces are: J. B. S. Haldane; Julian Huxley;
Robert Henlein, plastic-research engineer,
whose story "Solution Unsatisfactory," accu
rately predicted the international dilemma
resulting from the use of atomic weapons, and
of course, the old master, H. G. Wells, fiction's
most prolific inventor of fabulous gadgets.
SF readers are blasé, almost incapable of
surprise and amazement. To them "Astoynd
ing's" sundering of the atom was no more
exciting than splitting an infinitive. They've
seen everything, been everyplace — even be
yond the horizon and back.
For instance, who do you think sketched
the first workable blueprints for television?
It's Not Coincidence
Γ HE trouble with that complacent theory is
that "Astounding" — and sister newsstand
thrillers like "Startling," "Thrilling Wonder
Stories," "Planet" and "Amazing" — have
made Ux> many bull's-eye predictions to be
dismissed as "pure coincidence."
Today, there are approximately 250,000
devotees of science fiction in the United
States. They probably constitute the most
scientifically-hep reading public in magazine
appeared in 1941 as something new. But see panel on next page
